reviews.review_text: "The Sagas of the Icelanders" is a very eventful and entertaining book. The entire book contains a collection of tales, known as sagas, that took place in Iceland during the age of the Vikings. The tales are told in prose, but are not difficult to interpret, and there is also a bit of poetry for you poetry lovers. Although, the tales do show a lot of heroic moments and times of vengeance, there is also a lot of character development and connections within characters that are seen through tales about love, honor, betrayal, exploration, marriage, and other real-life occurrences, that are similar to the same life issues we deal with today. However, at that time in Iceland, things were handled in a slightly different way, and that's also what makes the book so interesting. You will get a good glimpse on the organization of their social status, government, religion, and other early Viking traditions.As you read through the sagas, you will start to notice that most the characters are transitioning from childhood to adulthood. There are also some characters who are mentioned in more than one saga, due to the fact that the sagas originate from one area (Iceland). For example, some characters are married or related to other characters in different sagas, within the book. I would have to say that is one thing that that makes the sagas somewhat confusing at times. Another thing that bothered me was the repetition of all the character names. Apparently, during the age of the Vikings, many people named their children after their relatives, so names are repeated entirely too much throughout the book. However, the good thing is, that the author constantly mentions nicknames and last names to help differentiate the characters, but I still think that it takes one to have some good memory to stay informed on what's taking place. I am not one who usually likes historical books or anything war-like, but this book is well worth exploring!
Gave this as a gift to a friend after we went to Iceland. He was delighted by it. Also, it was quite a bit cheaper on Amazon than it was in the Icelandic bookshop.

summary:
A unique body of medieval literature, the Sagas rank with the world's greatest literary treasures--as epic as Homer, as deep in tragedy as Sophocles, as engagingly human as Shakespeare. Set around the turn of the last millennium, these stories depict with an astonishingly modern realism the lives and deeds of the Norse men and women who first settled Iceland and of their descendants, who ventured further west--to Greenland and, ultimately, the coast of North America itself.

The ten Sagas and seven shorter tales in this volume include the celebrated "Vinland Sagas," which recount Leif Eiriksson's pioneering voyage to the New World and contain the oldest descriptions of the North American continent.

"One of the great marvels of World Literature.... This is a dream come true." Ted Hughes
